breakdown.heading: Transaction History ({{count}})
cex.chainalysisClearAddr: No sanctions identified. Exchanges are unlikely to flag this address.
cex.chainalysisClearTx: No sanctions identified. Exchanges are unlikely to flag this transaction.
cex.disclaimer: These checks cover sanctions screening only. Exchanges may flag addresses for other reasons (mixer usage, high-risk jurisdiction, etc.) that are not detectable with public tools.
cex.ofacClear: Checked against US Treasury SDN list. Client-side - no data sent.
cex.ofacFlaggedPlural: {{count}} sanctioned addresses found. Exchanges will likely freeze funds associated with these addresses.
cex.ofacFlaggedSingular: 1 sanctioned address found. Exchanges will likely freeze funds associated with this address.
cex.privacyNoteTor: Routed through Tor to protect your IP. Chainalysis sees the address but not your identity.
cex.privacyWarningPlural: Sends addresses to chainalysis.com via proxy. The proxy operator also sees the addresses.
cex.privacyWarningSingular: Sends address to chainalysis.com via proxy. The proxy operator also sees the addresses.
cex.sanctionsIdentified: Sanctions identified. Exchanges will likely freeze funds.
cex.torFailed: Tor proxy is unavailable. Proceeding will send the request directly - Chainalysis and the proxy operator will see your IP address.
cluster.coinJoinExcluded: {{count}} CoinJoin transaction excluded from clustering (CIOH does not apply).
cluster.description: Discover linked addresses using common-input-ownership heuristic (CIOH). Follows change outputs one hop. This makes additional API calls and may take a few seconds.
cluster.disclaimer: This is a lower-bound estimate based on one-hop CIOH analysis of the {{count}} most recent transactions. The actual cluster may be larger.
cluster.noLinked: No linked addresses found. This address does not share inputs with other addresses in analyzed transactions.
cluster.severityLarge: Large cluster: {{count}} addresses are linked through common inputs. A chain analysis firm can see all of them as belonging to the same entity.
cluster.severityNotable: Notable cluster: {{count}} addresses linked. Consider using CoinJoin before consolidating UTXOs.
cluster.severitySmall: Small cluster: {{count}} addresses linked through common inputs.
cluster.title: Cluster Analysis
common.connectionClearnet: Not using Tor - mempool.space can see your IP address
common.connectionTor: Connected via Tor - your IP is hidden from API providers
common.connectionUnknown: Connection privacy status could not be determined
common.privacyNotice: Queries are sent to mempool.space - your IP is visible. Use Tor or a VPN for stronger privacy.
common.tipMessage: am-i.exposed is free and open source. If it helped you, consider a tip.
common.tipScanQR: Scan with any Lightning wallet, or copy the address below
common.tipToastMessage: This tool is free and open source. Tip to keep it running.
crosspromo.stuckTx: Transaction stuck or slow? Unstick it in 3 clicks.
errors.address_not_found: Address not found. Check that it's correct and exists on the selected network.
errors.api_custom: Your custom API endpoint returned an error. Check that it is running.
errors.api_unavailable: The API is temporarily unavailable. Please try again later.
errors.api_unavailable_short: API temporarily unavailable. Try again later.
errors.boundary_description: An unexpected error occurred. This is usually temporary - try refreshing the page or starting over.
errors.invalid_input: Invalid Bitcoin address or transaction ID.
errors.network: Network error. Check your internet connection or try again later.
errors.network_custom: Connection to your custom endpoint failed. Open API settings to troubleshoot.
errors.network_short: Network error. Check your internet connection.
errors.not_found: Not found. Check that the address or transaction ID is correct and exists on the selected network.
errors.presend_txid: Pre-send check only works with addresses, not transaction IDs.
errors.rate_limited: Rate limited by mempool.space. Please wait a moment and try again.
errors.rate_limited_short: Rate limited. Please wait a moment and try again.
finding.anon-set-moderate.description: {{count}} outputs share the value {{value}}. This provides limited ambiguity.
finding.anon-set-moderate.recommendation: For stronger privacy, use CoinJoin to create larger anonymity sets (5+ equal outputs).
finding.anon-set-moderate.title: Anonymity set: {{count}} equal outputs
finding.anon-set-none.description: All {{outputCount}} outputs have unique values. Each output is trivially distinguishable, which is typical for standard transactions.
finding.anon-set-none.recommendation: This is normal for most transactions. CoinJoin creates larger anonymity sets for improved privacy.
finding.anon-set-none.title: No anonymity set (all outputs unique)
finding.anon-set-none.title_coinjoin: No anonymity set (all outputs unique) (CoinJoin - structural privacy)
finding.anon-set-strong.description: {{count}} outputs share the value {{value}}, creating an anonymity set of {{count}}. An observer cannot distinguish which input funded which of these {{count}} equal outputs.
finding.anon-set-strong.recommendation: Strong anonymity sets indicate good privacy. CoinJoin transactions maximize this property.
finding.anon-set-strong.title: Largest anonymity set: {{count}} outputs
finding.dust-attack.description: This transaction sends a tiny amount ({{totalDustValue}} sats) which is a common pattern in dust attacks. Attackers send small amounts to target addresses to track when the dust is spent, revealing wallet clusters. If you received this dust, do NOT spend it with your other UTXOs.
finding.dust-attack.recommendation: Mark this UTXO as 'do not spend' in your wallet. If you must consolidate, use a CoinJoin or send it to a completely separate wallet first. Many wallets support coin control to freeze individual UTXOs.
finding.dust-attack.title: Possible dust attack ({{totalDustValue}} sats)
finding.dust-attack.title_coinjoin: Possible dust attack ({{totalDustValue}} sats) (CoinJoin - likely coordinator fee)
finding.dust-outputs.description: This transaction contains {{dustCount}} outputs below {{threshold}} sats (total: {{totalDustValue}} sats). Tiny outputs are uneconomical to spend and may indicate dust for tracking purposes.
finding.dust-outputs.recommendation: Be cautious when spending dust UTXOs. Use coin control to avoid mixing them with your main UTXOs, which could link your addresses together.
finding.dust-outputs.title_coinjoin: {{dustCount}} dust outputs detected (CoinJoin - likely coordinator fee)
finding.h1-round-amount.description: {{count}} of {{total}} outputs are round numbers. Round payment amounts make it trivial to distinguish payments from change, revealing the exact amount sent and which output is change.
finding.h1-round-amount.recommendation: Avoid sending round BTC amounts. Many wallets let you send exact sat amounts. Even adding a few random sats helps obscure the payment amount.
finding.h1-round-amount.title: {{count}} round amount output detected
finding.h10-p2pkh.description: Legacy P2PKH addresses reveal the public key when spent, and have higher fees. While they have a large historical anonymity set, modern privacy tools and CoinJoin protocols primarily use newer address types.
finding.h10-p2pkh.recommendation: Upgrade to a native SegWit (bc1q) or Taproot (bc1p) wallet for better privacy and lower fees.
finding.h10-p2pkh.title: Legacy address (P2PKH)
finding.h10-p2sh.description: P2SH addresses reveal their script type on spend, reducing privacy. They also have a smaller anonymity set than native SegWit or Taproot addresses.
finding.h10-p2sh.recommendation: Upgrade to a native SegWit (bc1q) or Taproot (bc1p) wallet.
finding.h10-p2sh.title: Pay-to-Script-Hash address (P2SH)
finding.h10-p2tr.description: Taproot addresses provide the best on-chain privacy. When using key-path spends (the common case), all spend conditions - single-sig, multisig, timelocks - look identical on-chain, making transactions indistinguishable from each other.
finding.h10-p2tr.recommendation: You are using the most private address type available. Encourage others to adopt Taproot to grow the anonymity set.
finding.h10-p2tr.title: Taproot address (P2TR)
finding.h10-p2wpkh.description: P2WPKH is a good choice with a large anonymity set, but Taproot (P2TR) offers stronger privacy because all spend types look identical.
finding.h10-p2wpkh.recommendation: Consider upgrading to a Taproot-capable wallet for improved privacy.
finding.h10-p2wpkh.title: Native SegWit address (P2WPKH)
finding.h10-p2wsh.description: P2WSH is used for native SegWit multisig and complex scripts. The spending script is revealed on-chain when spent, which reduces privacy compared to Taproot where key-path spends hide the script.
finding.h10-p2wsh.recommendation: Consider upgrading to a Taproot-based multisig setup (MuSig2 or FROST) for improved privacy.
finding.h10-p2wsh.title: Native SegWit multisig address (P2WSH)
finding.h11-wallet-fingerprint.descripti: Transaction metadata reveals wallet characteristics: {{signals}}. Wallet identification helps chain analysts narrow down the software used, which combined with other data can aid in deanonymization.

Transaction metadata reveals wallet characteristics: {{signals}}. These signals are consistent with {{walletGuess}}. Wallet identification helps chain analysts narrow down the software used, which combined with other data can aid in deanonymization.
finding.h11-wallet-fingerprint.recommend: Wallet fingerprinting is difficult to avoid without modifying wallet software. Taproot (P2TR) transactions help because key-path spends all look identical. Using popular wallets with large user bases reduces the identifying power of fingerprints.
finding.h13-ofac-match.description: This address matches an entry on the U.S. Treasury OFAC Specially Designated Nationals (SDN) list. Transacting with sanctioned addresses may have serious legal consequences.
finding.h13-ofac-match.recommendation: Do NOT send funds to this address. Consult legal counsel if you have already transacted with this address.
finding.h13-ofac-match.title: OFAC sanctioned address
finding.h13-presend-check.recommendation: This destination looks clean. You can proceed with your transaction.
Ask the recipient for a fresh, unused address. If this is an exchange, consider the privacy implications.
finding.h13-presend-check.title: Destination risk: {{riskLevel}}
finding.h2-change-detected.description: {{signalCount}} sub-heuristics point to a likely change output. When the change output is known, the exact payment amount and recipient are revealed.
finding.h2-change-detected.recommendatio: Use wallets with change output randomization. Avoid round payment amounts. Consider using the same address type for all outputs (Taproot makes this easier).
finding.h2-change-detected.title: Change output likely identifiable ({{confidence}} confidence)
finding.h2-change-detected.title_coinjoi: Change output likely identifiable ({{confidence}} confidence) (CoinJoin - unreliable)
finding.h3-cioh.description: This transaction combines inputs from {{count}} different addresses. Chain analysis firms will assume these {{count}} addresses belong to the same entity. This assumption is probabilistic but widely applied in commercial chain surveillance.
finding.h3-cioh.recommendation: Use coin control to avoid combining UTXOs from different addresses. If consolidation is necessary, use CoinJoin first to break the link between source addresses.
finding.h3-cioh.title: {{count}} input addresses linked by CIOH
finding.h3-cioh.title_coinjoin: {{count}} input addresses linked by CIOH (CoinJoin - expected)
finding.h3-single-input.description: This transaction uses a single input address, so the common-input-ownership heuristic does not apply. No address clustering is possible from inputs alone.
finding.h3-single-input.recommendation: Keep using single-input transactions when possible.
finding.h3-single-input.title: Single input address
finding.h4-coinjoin.description: {{count}} of {{total}} outputs have the same value ({{denomination}}). This pattern is characteristic of collaborative CoinJoin transactions that break the link between inputs and outputs, significantly improving privacy.
finding.h4-coinjoin.description_wabisabi: This transaction has {{vin}} inputs and {{vout}} outputs with {{groups}} groups of equal-value outputs, consistent with a WabiSabi (Wasabi Wallet 2.0) CoinJoin using multiple denomination tiers. This pattern breaks the link between inputs and outputs, significantly improving privacy.
finding.h4-coinjoin.recommendation: CoinJoin is a strong privacy technique. For maximum benefit, ensure you are using a reputable CoinJoin coordinator and consider multiple rounds.
finding.h4-coinjoin.recommendation_wabis: WabiSabi CoinJoins provide excellent privacy through large anonymity sets and multiple denomination tiers. Continue using CoinJoin for maximum privacy.
finding.h4-coinjoin.title: Likely CoinJoin: {{count}} equal outputs of {{denomination}}
finding.h4-coinjoin.title_wabisabi: WabiSabi CoinJoin: {{groups}} denomination tiers, {{totalEqual}} equal outputs across {{vout}} total
finding.h4-whirlpool.description: This transaction matches the Whirlpool CoinJoin pattern: 5 equal outputs at a standard denomination. Whirlpool provides strong forward-looking privacy by breaking deterministic transaction links.
finding.h4-whirlpool.recommendation: Whirlpool is one of the strongest CoinJoin implementations. Make sure to also remix (multiple rounds) for maximum privacy.
finding.h4-whirlpool.title: Whirlpool CoinJoin detected ({{denom}} pool)
finding.h5-entropy.description: This transaction has {{entropy}} bits of entropy (via {{method}}), meaning there are ~{{interpretations}} valid interpretations of the fund flow. Higher entropy makes chain analysis less reliable.
finding.h5-entropy.recommendation_high: Good entropy level. CoinJoin transactions can achieve even higher entropy.
finding.h5-entropy.recommendation_low: Consider using CoinJoin to significantly increase transaction entropy.
finding.h5-entropy.title: Transaction entropy: {{entropy}} bits
finding.h5-low-entropy.description: This transaction has near-zero entropy ({{entropy}} bits, via {{method}}). There is essentially only one valid interpretation of the fund flow, making it trivial to trace.
finding.h5-low-entropy.recommendation: Higher entropy transactions are harder to trace. Consider using CoinJoin to maximize transaction ambiguity.
finding.h5-low-entropy.title: Very low transaction entropy
finding.h5-zero-entropy.description: This transaction has a single input and single output, meaning there is only one possible interpretation. No ambiguity exists about the flow of funds.
finding.h5-zero-entropy.recommendation: Transactions with more inputs and outputs naturally have higher entropy. CoinJoin transactions maximize entropy.
finding.h5-zero-entropy.title: Zero transaction entropy
finding.h6-rbf-signaled.description: This transaction signals RBF replaceability (nSequence < 0xfffffffe). While RBF itself is not a privacy concern, it reveals that the sender's wallet supports fee bumping, which narrows down the wallet software used.
finding.h6-rbf-signaled.recommendation: RBF is generally recommended for fee management. As more wallets adopt it, this signal becomes less identifying.
finding.h6-rbf-signaled.title: RBF (Replace-by-Fee) signaled
finding.h6-round-fee-rate.description: This transaction uses an exact integer fee rate of {{feeRate}} sat/vB. Some wallet software uses round fee rates rather than precise estimates, which can help identify the wallet used.
finding.h6-round-fee-rate.recommendation: This is a minor signal. Most modern wallets now use precise fee estimation.
finding.h6-round-fee-rate.title: Exact fee rate: {{feeRate}} sat/vB
finding.h6-round-fee-rate.title_coinjoin: Exact fee rate: {{feeRate}} sat/vB (CoinJoin - coordinator fee)
finding.h7-op-return.description: This transaction embeds data permanently in the blockchain via OP_RETURN. This data is publicly visible forever.
finding.h7-op-return.description_decoded: This transaction embeds data permanently in the blockchain via OP_RETURN. This data is publicly visible forever. Decoded text: "{{decoded}}".
finding.h7-op-return.description_protoco: This transaction embeds data permanently in the blockchain via OP_RETURN. This data is publicly visible forever. Detected protocol: {{protocol}}.
finding.h7-op-return.recommendation: Be aware that OP_RETURN data is permanent and public. Avoid transactions that embed unnecessary metadata if privacy is a concern.
finding.h7-op-return.title: OP_RETURN data embedded in transaction
finding.h8-address-reuse.description: This address appears in {{txCount}} transactions. Every transaction to and from this address is now trivially linkable by chain analysis. Address reuse is the single most damaging privacy practice in Bitcoin.
finding.h8-address-reuse.recommendation: Use a wallet that generates a new address for every receive (HD wallets). Never share the same address twice. Consider consolidating funds to a new address via CoinJoin.
finding.h8-address-reuse.title: Address reused across {{txCount}} transactions
finding.h8-batch-receive.description: This address received {{totalFunded}} outputs in a single transaction, likely a batched payment. While this creates multiple UTXOs, it does not constitute address reuse since only one transaction is involved.
finding.h8-batch-receive.recommendation: This is typically caused by exchange batched withdrawals. Use a fresh address for the next receive.
finding.h8-batch-receive.title: Multiple UTXOs from a single transaction (batch payment)
finding.h8-no-reuse.description: This address has only received funds once. Single-use addresses are a core Bitcoin privacy practice.
finding.h8-no-reuse.recommendation: Keep using fresh addresses for every receive.
finding.h8-no-reuse.title: No address reuse detected
finding.h9-clean.description: No dust UTXOs detected and the UTXO count is manageable. This is a healthy state for privacy.
finding.h9-clean.title: Clean UTXO set
finding.h9-dust-detected.description: Found {{dustCount}} UTXOs below {{threshold}} sats (total: {{totalDust}} sats). Tiny unsolicited UTXOs are often "dusting attacks" - surveillance entities send small amounts to track your spending. When you spend dust alongside other UTXOs, it links those UTXOs together via the common-input-ownership heuristic.
finding.h9-dust-detected.recommendation: Do NOT spend these dust UTXOs. Freeze them in your wallet's coin control feature. If your wallet does not support coin control, consider switching to one that does (Sparrow, Bitcoin Core).
finding.h9-many-utxos.description: This address holds {{utxoCount}} UTXOs. Spending multiple UTXOs in a single transaction links them together via CIOH, reducing privacy. Large UTXO sets also increase transaction fees.
finding.h9-many-utxos.recommendation: Consider consolidating UTXOs during low-fee periods using coin control, or run them through a CoinJoin to break linkability before consolidation.
finding.h9-many-utxos.title: Large UTXO set ({{utxoCount}} UTXOs)
finding.h9-moderate-utxos.description: This address has {{utxoCount}} UTXOs. Be mindful when spending - combining UTXOs in a single transaction reveals common ownership.
finding.h9-moderate-utxos.recommendation: Use coin control to select specific UTXOs when sending. Avoid auto-selection that combines all UTXOs.
finding.h9-moderate-utxos.title: {{utxoCount}} UTXOs on this address
finding.partial-history.description_part: This address has {{totalOnChain}} total transactions but only the most recent {{txsAnalyzed}} were analyzed. Older transactions may contain additional privacy-relevant patterns not reflected in these results.
finding.partial-history.description_unav: This address has {{totalOnChain}} transactions but transaction history could not be fetched. Spending pattern analysis could not be performed, so the score may be incomplete.
finding.partial-history.recommendation_p: For a complete analysis of high-activity addresses, consider running a full node with a local Electrum server.
finding.partial-history.recommendation_u: Try again later, or use a custom API endpoint with higher rate limits.
finding.script-mixed.description: This transaction uses {{typeCount}} different script types ({{types}}). Mixing script types makes change detection easier and can fingerprint the wallet software.
finding.script-mixed.recommendation: Use a wallet that sends change to the same address type as the inputs. Taproot (P2TR) unifies all script types.
finding.script-mixed.title: {{typeCount}} different script types in transaction
finding.script-mixed.title_coinjoin: {{typeCount}} different script types in transaction (CoinJoin - expected)
finding.script-multisig.description: This transaction contains {{count}} bare multisig (P2MS) outputs. Bare multisig exposes ALL public keys directly on the blockchain, making it trivial to identify the signing parties. This is a legacy pattern that should be avoided.
finding.script-multisig.recommendation: Use P2SH-wrapped or P2WSH-wrapped multisig instead of bare multisig. Better yet, use Taproot (P2TR) with MuSig2 or FROST for multisig that looks identical to single-sig on-chain.
finding.script-uniform.description: All inputs and outputs use the same script type, making change detection harder. An observer cannot use script type mismatch to identify the change output.
finding.script-uniform.recommendation: Continue using wallets that maintain consistent address types.
finding.script-uniform.title: Uniform script types
finding.spending-high-volume.description: This address has been involved in {{totalTxs}} transactions. High-volume addresses are more likely to be monitored by chain analysis firms and may be associated with services, exchanges, or businesses.
finding.spending-high-volume.recommendat: Use HD wallets to spread activity across many addresses. Avoid concentrating activity on a single address.
finding.spending-high-volume.title: High transaction volume ({{totalTxs}} transactions)
finding.spending-many-counterparties.des: This address has sent or received funds involving {{counterpartyCount}}+ different addresses. A large number of counterparties creates a wide exposure surface and makes the address easier to cluster with other known entities.
finding.spending-many-counterparties.rec: Use separate addresses for different transaction partners. HD wallets do this automatically.
finding.spending-never-spent.description: This address has received funds but never spent them. This is characteristic of cold storage, which is good for security. Since no spend transactions exist, no on-chain spending patterns can be analyzed.
finding.spending-never-spent.recommendat: When you do spend from this address, use coin control and consider CoinJoin.
finding.spending-never-spent.title: Address has never spent (cold storage)
finding.timing-locktime-timestamp.descri: This transaction uses nLockTime as a UNIX timestamp ({{locktime}}), which is unusual. Most wallets use block-height-based locktime or 0. Timestamp-based locktime can reveal the intended broadcast time and narrow down when the transaction was created.
finding.timing-locktime-timestamp.recomm: Use wallets that set nLockTime to the current block height (anti-fee-sniping) rather than timestamps. Bitcoin Core and Sparrow do this by default.
finding.timing-locktime-timestamp.title: nLockTime set to timestamp ({{date}})
finding.timing-stale-locktime.descriptio: The nLockTime ({{locktime}}) is {{diff}} blocks before the confirmation height ({{blockHeight}}). This suggests the transaction was created well before it was broadcast, or was deliberately delayed. This can reveal information about the sender's transaction preparation patterns.
finding.timing-stale-locktime.recommenda: Broadcast transactions promptly after creation. Long delays between creation and broadcast can be detected and may reveal transaction batching behavior.
finding.timing-stale-locktime.title: Transaction held for ~{{diff}} blocks before confirmation
finding.timing-unconfirmed.description: This transaction has not yet been confirmed in a block. Unconfirmed transactions are visible in the mempool, meaning anyone monitoring the P2P network could have seen when your node broadcast it, potentially correlating your IP address with this transaction.
finding.timing-unconfirmed.recommendatio: When broadcasting sensitive transactions, use Tor to connect to the Bitcoin network. Consider using a wallet that broadcasts via Tor by default (Sparrow, Wasabi).
finding.timing-unconfirmed.title: Transaction is unconfirmed (mempool visible)
input.descriptionCheck: Check a destination address before you send bitcoin to it
input.descriptionScan: Analyze your address or transaction for privacy leaks
input.errorInvalid: That doesn't look like a Bitcoin address or txid. Check and try again.
input.placeholderScan: Paste a Bitcoin address or transaction ID
install.description: Install as an app for faster access. No app store needed.
install.title: Install am-i.exposed
methodology.english_only: The methodology page content is available in English only.
methodology.title: Methodology
page.description: Find out what the blockchain knows about you. Paste a Bitcoin address or transaction ID to get a privacy score with actionable findings.
page.tagline: The Bitcoin privacy scanner you were afraid to run.
presend.adviceCritical: Do NOT send to this address. It poses severe privacy or legal risks.
presend.adviceHigh: Ask the recipient for a fresh, unused address before sending.
presend.adviceLow: This destination looks safe to send to.
presend.adviceMedium: Consider asking the recipient for a fresh address.
presend.disclaimerBrowser: Analysis ran entirely in your browser. This is a heuristic-based assessment - always verify independently.
presend.reusedAddressWarning: Sending to a reused address links your transaction to all other transactions involving this address. Chain analysis can trivially trace your payment.
recent.title: Recent scans
remediation.avoidAddressReuseDetail: Use a new address for each transaction. Enable HD wallet features if available.
remediation.avoidOpReturn: Avoid services that embed OP_RETURN data
remediation.avoidOpReturnDetail: OP_RETURN data is permanent and public. If a service you use embeds data in transactions, consider alternatives that don't leave metadata on-chain.
remediation.betterChangeHandling: Use wallets with better change handling
remediation.betterChangeHandlingDetail: Switch to a wallet that uses the same address type for change as for payments. Taproot (P2TR) wallets like Sparrow or Blue Wallet help with this.
remediation.continueCoinJoinDetail: Your CoinJoin transaction provides strong privacy. Continue using Whirlpool or Wasabi for future transactions. Avoid consolidating CoinJoin outputs with non-CoinJoin UTXOs.
remediation.doNotSpendDust: Do NOT spend the dust output
remediation.doNotSpendDustDetail: Freeze this UTXO in your wallet's coin control. Spending it will link your addresses. If you must clean it up, send it through a CoinJoin first.
remediation.freshStart: Consider a fresh start with better privacy practices
remediation.freshStartDetail: Use a privacy-focused wallet (Sparrow, Wasabi), generate a new seed, and send funds through a CoinJoin before depositing to the new wallet. Use Tor for all Bitcoin network activity.
remediation.minimizeMultiInputDetail: Consolidating UTXOs links your addresses together. Use coin control to avoid spending from multiple addresses in one transaction. If you must consolidate, do it through a CoinJoin.
remediation.stopReusingAddressDetail: Generate a new address for every receive. Most wallets do this automatically. Send remaining funds to a fresh wallet using a CoinJoin or intermediate address.
remediation.switchMultisig: Switch from bare multisig to Taproot MuSig2
remediation.switchMultisigDetail: Bare multisig exposes all public keys on-chain. Use P2WSH-wrapped multisig at minimum, or ideally Taproot with MuSig2/FROST which looks identical to single-sig.
remediation.upgradeTaprootDetail: Taproot addresses (bc1p...) provide the best privacy by making all transactions look identical on-chain. They also have lower fees. Sparrow, Blue Wallet, and Bitcoin Core all support Taproot.
remediation.usePayJoin: Use PayJoin or CoinJoin for better transaction entropy
remediation.usePayJoinDetail: Simple 1-in/2-out transactions have low entropy, making analysis straightforward. PayJoin (BIP78) adds inputs from the receiver to break common analysis heuristics.
remediation.walletFingerprint: Consider wallet software with better fingerprint resistance
remediation.walletFingerprintDetail: Your wallet software can be identified through transaction patterns. Bitcoin Core, Sparrow, and Wasabi have the best fingerprint resistance.
results.disclaimerBrowser: Analysis ran entirely in your browser.
results.disclaimerHeuristic: Scores are heuristic-based estimates, not definitive privacy assessments.
results.fGradeWarningAddr: This address has severe privacy issues. On-chain surveillance can likely identify the owner and trace fund flows. Immediate remediation steps are recommended below.
results.fGradeWarningTx: This transaction has severe privacy issues. On-chain surveillance can likely identify the owner and trace fund flows. Immediate remediation steps are recommended below.
results.scoringExplainerP1b: (baseline) and are adjusted by each heuristic finding. Negative findings (address reuse, change detection, round amounts) lower the score. Positive findings (CoinJoin, high entropy, anonymity sets) raise it.
results.scoringExplainerP3: The engine runs 16 heuristics based on published chain analysis research. Scores are clamped to 0-100. CoinJoin transactions receive adjusted scoring that accounts for their privacy-enhancing properties.
settings.corsExplanation2: to accept requests from this site. Add this to your mempool nginx config:
settings.optionADesc: Forward your node to localhost to avoid mixed-content blocking:
settings.optionBDesc: Set up HTTPS on your node with Caddy or nginx + Let's Encrypt, add CORS headers, then use your HTTPS URL.
settings.optionCDesc: If this site has a .onion mirror, use Tor Browser to visit it and enter your mempool
settings.selfHostHint: Point to your own mempool.space instance for maximum privacy.
settings.title: API endpoint settings
step.anon.label: Anonymity sets
step.dust.label: Dust output detection
step.h1.label: Round amounts
step.h10.label: Address type
step.h11.label: Wallet fingerprinting
step.h2.label: Change detection
step.h3.label: Common input ownership
step.h4.label: CoinJoin detection
step.h5.label: Transaction entropy
step.h6.label: Fee fingerprinting
step.h7.label: OP_RETURN metadata
step.h8.label: Address reuse
step.h9.label: UTXO analysis
step.script.label: Script type analysis
step.spending.label: Spending patterns
step.timing.label: Timing analysis
tips.0: Never reuse a Bitcoin address. HD wallets generate a new address for each receive automatically.
tips.1: CoinJoin breaks the common-input-ownership heuristic, making chain analysis significantly harder.
tips.2: Use Tor when broadcasting transactions. Your IP can be correlated with your on-chain activity.
tips.3: Round payment amounts (e.g., 0.01 BTC) reveal which output is the payment and which is change.
tips.4: Taproot (bc1p...) addresses make all transaction types look identical on-chain.
tips.5: Dust outputs (< 1000 sats) may be surveillance dust. Freeze them in your wallet's coin control.
tips.6: Wallet software can be identified through nLockTime, nSequence, and signature patterns.
tips.7: PayJoin has the receiver contribute an input, breaking the assumption that all inputs belong to the sender.
